body:
I haven't read the diff yet, but I'm excited to see this. I always had
this kind of optimization -- and Robin Hood hashing in particular --
in mind as a great project.
If you are unzipping, it seems essential to use unsafe code and raw pointers, so that you the vector length and capacity is stored once instead of 3 times, and bounds checking is not done 3 times.
I think I broke the borrow checker. Would someone mind checking out this branch and giving me a hand with fixing the errors?

However, it doesn't bootstrap due to failing an assertion compiling stage1 std:

```
Ok(task 'rustc' failed at 'assertion failed: `(left == right) && (right == left)` (left: `24u`, right: `27u`)', [...]/rust/src/libstd/hashmap.rs:916
```
Thanks a lot guys! @huonw: Yeah I kinda figured it'd fail somewhere. Didn't really get a chance to test my latest changes :P
Okay this is fixed now, and ready for some more intense review!
You've done an awesome job containing the unsafety of this implementation, thank you!

FWIW, the performance difference (if there is a significant one) due to adding/removing `#[inline]`'s is likely to be only visible outside libstd (i.e. any `#[bench]`'s in libstd are not cross crate, and so are only slightly affected by `#[inline]`.)

Overall, I think I'm still quite uneasy with the amount of unsafe code in this patch. I haven't found anything glaringly wrong in the _current_ usage of it, but I that doesn't rule out possible future refactorings.

One interesting route which could be taken is to implement the `RawTable` data structure on top of `vec_ng::Vec` with 0 unsafe code. At that point, you're guaranteed you have a safe api, albeit with a few too many runtime assertions. At that stage, I would expect a full set of benchmarks and numbers to be collected.

The next step would be to take this safe interface and then reimplement it all with unsafe arrays (as you have now). After this is done, another full set of benchmarks and numbers would be collected, and we could compare the impact of the two implementations.

I do realize that implementing a safe interface may be a difficult thing to do, but I'm still not quite convinced that the fundamental hash map of the language should be unsafely implemented. Others may disagree though.

I admire your dedication to safe code. Few people would've pushed me as hard as you have to think of safe alternatives to unsafe operations.

And just to be clear, you're talking about implementing on top of `vec_ng::Vec<Option<u64, K, V>>`, right? Because that wastes a bunch of memory for reasons talked about way too much.

There's also `(vec_ng::Vec<u64>, vec_ng::Vec<V>, vec_ng::Vec<V>)` which I can build it on top of, but now that's "unsafe" in the sense that the sizes could be out of line. It also wastes 4 words in the data structure storing redundant capacities and sizes.

I think the expectation of the standard library of any language is that it performs well, and doesn't provide a way for the end user to break it horribly. For example, I don't think anyone would be surprised if Vec had unsafe code, but I think many people would be surprised if it was noticeably slower than an array for simple tasks. Trading off any performance here for a safer implementation (as opposed to API) is surprising.

Like you, though, I'm still suspicious of this code. But, as a core data structure, I think we can rely on the sheer volume of usage that it gets to iron out bugs. Pretty much every single application will use a hashtable for something. Figuring out what triggers some of these asserts will certainly be interesting.

Yes, I'm suggesting that this starts out by implementing on top of `vec_ng::Vec<Option<u64, K, V>>` and then after that's working it's reimplemented with the same interface but with the same unzipped implementation you have now.

As we've discovered, the `RawTable` type has an unsafe interface, even though it pretends to be safe. By implementing `RawTable` with `vec_ng::Vec` a safe interface can be created for later underlying implementation adjustment.

I'm not saying that this should use `vec_ng::Vec` for an implementation. I'm saying that this should be first implemented with `vec_ng::Vec` to discover what a safe interface would look like and then it's reimplemented with unsafe code for speed. The measurements would also tell us whether the unsafe code is worth it or not.

I don't see how that's better than what we have now with the asserts. No invariant (that isn't protected against statically) goes unasserted for each of the "unsafe" function. That's basically all we'd be getting by switching to the vector of options.

That implies that we need the assertions for correctness, which I would rather not have. By using a safe interface we can assert that everything is statically correct, and the assertions are purely debug-only for now.

Well, the interface with options and a vector isn't really "safe". i.e. the risk of indexing out of bounds and grabbing a bucket which is `None` is exactly as it is now: failure with a message.

I thought rust asserts were for both debug and non-debug mode! I removed the `if cfg(debug)` blocks around it until the codebase matures more; hopefully I can replace them with "debug-mode only" asserts before 1.0.

> No invariant (that isn't protected against statically) goes unasserted for each of the "unsafe" function

Are you totally 100% sure that _every_ invariant is checked/asserted?

(I think that's the benefit of safe code: the compiler won't let _anything_ accidentally slip by.)

Of the ones that would be fixed by using a vector of options, yes. Of other, possibly unknown invariants, no.

The vector enforces out-of-bounds. This is checked with an assert.
The option ensures that I can't take twice out of the same bucket, nor put twice into the same bucket. Nor read from a bucket that's empty. All of these are also checked with asserts.

There's nothing really else it can do..

The RawTable interface is only unsafe because it's badly designed.

If you make FullIndex, EmptyIndex (and thus BucketState) take a lifetime parameter with the same lifetime of the &mut self, and move the RawTable &mut self reference to a private field inside them, then it's no longer unsafe, and it is statically checked that you can't take twice from the same bucket, etc.

I think I commented with the exact code to do this, but it's pretty obvious.
@bill-myers doesn't work when you need to modify two different buckets at once (as @cgaebel said when you commented originally).

In which case is modifying two buckets at once required?

If it's just for a swap, I suppose you could add a search_another method to FullIndex that returns a either the same FullIndex (if it found the same bucket), or a TwoFullIndices or a FullAndEmptyIndex type.

I can't find any code that modifies two buckets at once though, but maybe I'm missing it.
@bill-myers, please keep in mind our [code of conduct](https://github.com/mozilla/rust/wiki/Note-development-policy#wiki-conduct), especially bullet 3.

Looks like, to make that word, one should make `robin_hood` and `bucket_distance` methods on FullIndex (in general anything that requires a FullIndex needs to be a method on FullIndex), and `pop` should either be mostly moved to RawTable, or perhaps based on an interface that returns an iterator for the whole run and can do the shift operation.

This does perhaps move the problem to having a more complex RawTable/FullIndex/EmptyIndex though.

But it's kind of hard to plan this in advance, it would require to implement it, look at the fallout, refactor, and iterate until a minimal and correct interface is achieved.

@bill-myers: I like that idea in theory and tried it out. It ends up migrating the bulk of the code into `RawTable`, making the whole reason for its existence (isolating the unsafe operations) pointless.

Anyhow, I've rebased this now that it seems discussion died down. r?
I'm a little worried about the number of `FIXME` annotations you have throughout the hashmap now. It would be nice to see some of them get addressed or perhaps consolidated.
I consolidated the FIXMEs into the big block comment above the `HashMap` struct definition.
@cgaebel Can you squash these commits?
Done.
@alexcrichton Is this mergeable? It can be improved upon later.

So this won't build, because it complains about an unused import. When I remove that import, I can't build because that import is actually used. Would someone mind taking a look at it for me? This is probably a compiler bug.
Which import?
Check the travis build. `std::hash::sip`.

Just FYI, I put this on the agenda for the next meeting. At this point, I'm generally in favor of merging. However I confess I have failed to read this PR in depth and I plan to do so before the next meeting, but I think we really need a performant and optimized hashtable. I do think we should insert dynamic assertions (disabled in optimized builds) testing the expected invariants and so on.
I'm not even sure how much controversy there is at this point, just thought I'd throw out my 2 cents ;)
Added the "debug asserts" referencing #12049.
@cgaebel it's probably a staging thing. You might need a `#[cfg(not(stage0))] use ...` or something.
Naw huon got it. It was just me not looking at the line numbers and being confused. This should be good to merge.
/me quietly sits on his hands
BTW, are the numbers in the PR description still current with the various changes that have been made?
No, but should be same ballpark. Nothing major that should affect performance has changed.

On a recent flight, I finally found the time to read the PR in
depth. This is some excellent work. I am satisfied with the
refactoring of the unsafe bits combined with the usage assertions,
it's even better than what I had in mind. I think though I have some
ideas for how to statically verify the usage of FullIndex and friends
are used properly, but this could be a follow-up PR (and I have to try
it out, there might be a complication I have not foreseen).

I will look over my notes later today and add them into the PR.  I
seem to recall that mostly I just had nits, apart from my thoughts on
how to make it safer.

Regarding the mutable iterator in specific -- I think you could make
it "safe" along the model of the vector iterators, by having the
iterator take mutable slices that it shrinks for each step. But this
is just trading one unsafety for another, since those slices would
contain partially initialized data, and the compiler would be unaware
of it. I think the current setup (artifically prolonging the lifetime)
is a smaller sin.

(So I investigated my "safety" ideas a bit more. I think it can be done, but it's a non-trivial patch, and it's unclear if the resulting code is clearer. It would be somewhat nicer if we could parameterize over mutability, though using traits it might be possible to write the relevant code generically. Regardless, as the patch'd be non-trivial, it might affect perf, and it may not be more readable really, so I think it ought to be considered as a follow up.)

The unsafety is unfortunate but we can't ignore this perf improvement. Let's land this but please do keep trying to abstract out the unsafe code here.

@cgaebel Thanks.
The public interface is safe. What pieces of unsafety should I focus on? The "double-take bug"?
Feel free to comment on the PR whenever you force push, sadly none of us get notifications!
Oops. /pushed

> The public interface is safe. What pieces of unsafety should I focus on? The "double-take bug"?

Note: I have an in-progress branch addressing the double take bug. I'll push it somewhere public.
Force pushed.
BTW, this reduced rustc's memory use (for building `librustc`) by ~100MB: http://huonw.github.io/isrustfastyet/mem/#2eebeb8,4d64441
NICE! Btw is that a CPU usage regression, or just noise?

noise. I was probably building another copy of rustc at the time, or
playing a game.

On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 11:03 AM, Clark Gaebel notifications@github.comwrote:

> NICE! Btw is that a CPU usage regression, or just noise?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/mozilla/rust/pull/12081#issuecomment-37825672
> .
